title: GitHub - jparise/chrome-utm-stripper: Browser extension that strips Google Analytics (UTM) parameters, and various other click tracking tokens, from URL query strings

last_post.content:
When you click on or share links, often there are tracking tokens added to the URL, like fbclid (Facebook tracking).
You can automatically strip tracking tokens by installing this extension for Chrome or Firefox: https://github.com/jparise/chrome-utm-stripper
For Android, use the Firefox browser app and install the Ublock Origin ad blocker extension: https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/android/addon/ublock-origin/
Then go to the Ublock dashboard settings->My filters, and paste in the *$removeparam lines from this post: https://www.adamsdesk.com/posts/remove-tracking-parameters/
#EdTech

I don’t know if this is the same on other platforms/languages but #Apple #Swift support for image metadata retrieval seems to be rather pitiful 😛 I tried multiple different suggested approaches and lirbaries and all I get are around 4 - 5 meta data items for a particular image.

I use exiftool (https://exiftool.org/) and I get around 20+ metadata items for the same file.

So I resorted to this exiftool wrapper — https://github.com/hlemai/ExifTool It is supposed to be using the exiftool libraries but even that got only 18 items and it left out the one item I was actually interested in 😛

So I finally ended up writing some custom code which would run exiftool locally as a task, get the output of the command and then parse the output to get the metadata. That finally worked for me…

But should I have to go through all these hoops to get image metadata when using Swift? I would have thought there was a simpler/easier solution?

Does anyone know of one?

I’m almost tempted to write my own solution in Swift where I read the image raw data, parse the header and get the metadata. But do I really want to? Probably not …

#Apple #Swift #Images #Metadata #Coding

I don’t know if this is the same on other platforms/languages but #Apple #Swift support for image metadata retrieval seems to be rather pitiful 😛 I tried multiple different suggested approaches and lirbaries and all I get are around 4 - 5 meta data items for a particular image.

I use exiftool (https://exiftool.org/) and I get around 20+ metadata items for the same file.

So I resorted to this exiftool wrapper — https://github.com/hlemai/ExifTool It is supposed to be using the exiftool libraries but even that got only 18 items and it left out the one item I was actually interested in 😛

So I finally ended up writing some custom code which would run exiftool locally as a task, get the output of the command and then parse the output to get the metadata. That finally worked for me…

But should I have to go through all these hoops to get image metadata when using Swift? I would have thought there was a simpler/easier solution?

Does anyone know of one?

I’m almost tempted to write my own solution in Swift where I read the image raw data, parse the header and get the metadata. But do I really want to? Probably not …

Yesterday's Pratchett novel title prompt was: "Raising Steam".

Here's the thing about the prompt — I generated images on macOS initially and I was happy with the images I was getting since I was getting strange stuff. Nothing really to do with the prompt possibly, but all sorts of weird and wonderful landscapes 🙂

Then I switched to Windows for generation and suddenly all I'd get were trains or some sort of steam engine. Not a lot of variety ... No matter how many models I tried 😛

I've selected a mixed set from both sides for fair representation but I feel as if this needs more exploration ...

title:
Curio Esoterica on Instagram: "90’s witches and their computers: First, an incredibly hard-to-pin image, this illustration is by Tristan Elwell, and it adorns the cover of the 1997 edition of Vivian Van Velde’s “Curses, Inc. and Other Stories.” It often floats around the web unattributed, so I felt it was high time to track it down. It took me ages, but using TinEye and Archive.org, I was able to access an original copy. Another win for digital libraries in the realm of attribution. This young adult collection includes mysteries and haunting stories like “Witch Hunt,” and “The Witches’ Son.” It likely spurned a lifetime of interest in witchcraft, paganism, and magic in a generation of 90’s kids (much to the chagrin, surely, of their parents & guardians!).
•••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••
The second image is a photo of the storied and influential Wiccan writer and thinker Stewart Farrar (1916-2000) as he sits at his home computer. The photo was taken by Bev Richardson, and is likely c.a. 1997 — roughly the same era (and era of computer) as Van Velde’s book. Farrar was known for his partnership with Janet Farrar, with whom he co-authored the 1996 book “The Witches’ Bible: The Complete Witches’ Handbook” — a work which perhaps succeeded Van Velde’s book in the trajectory of increased witchcraft readership amongst young people of the 90’s.
•••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••
Digital community building was a seemingly essential ingredient in the formation of global neopagan, Wiccan, and witchcraft communities during the 1990’s.

During 1997, roughly around the same time as both of these images were produced, Wren Walker and Fritz Jun founded “The Witches’ Voice,” better known as “WitchVox.” Around 2004, I recall it was an essential tool for me to at least *know* that there were viable communities of pagans and occultists in my area. Do you have any early-digital, or WitchVox-related nostalgia?
•••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••
#witches #witchcraftart #magiccircle #illustrationart #scrying #digitalmagic #cybermagic #occultart #occultbooks #stewartfarrar #wiccans #wicca #neopaganism #witchvox"
